content:
I’ve loved making things for as long as I can remember. I work to design high performance mechanisms with complex behaviours yet minimal embodiments, exploiting manufacturing constraints to obtain high efficiency and reduced costs.
Questa pagina presenta una panoramica del mio lavoro degli ultimi anni.
Breve Biografia Nel 2006 ho conseguito la Laurea Magistrale con lode in Ingegneria Meccanica dall’Università degli Studi di Modena e Reggio Emilia. Mi sono poi trasferito a Genova dove ho iniziato il dottorato di ricerca all’Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia (IIT). In IIT ho lavorato allo sviluppo hardware del robot umanoide iCub con Lorenzo Natale, Giorgio Metta and Giulio Sandini.
Dopo aver conseguito il dottorato sono rimasto in IIT, dove ho assunto la guida dello sviluppo hardware del progetto iCub, come PostDoc a partire dal 2010 e come Tecnologo dal 2016. Nell’agosto del 2019 sono diventato il coordinatore della facility IIT per la progettazione e la costruzione di sistemi meccanici.
summary:
I’ve loved making things for as long as I can remember. I work to design high performance mechanisms with complex behaviours yet minimal embodiments, exploiting manufacturing constraints to obtain high efficiency and reduced costs.
Questa pagina presenta una panoramica del mio lavoro degli ultimi anni.
Breve Biografia Nel 2006 ho conseguito la Laurea Magistrale con lode in Ingegneria Meccanica dall’Università degli Studi di Modena e Reggio Emilia. Mi sono poi trasferito a Genova dove ho iniziato il dottorato di ricerca all’Istituto Italiano di Tecnologia (IIT).
title: Alberto Parmiggiani
A Comparison of Robot Wrist Implementations for the iCub Humanoid
Design and Control of a Passive Noise Rejecting Variable Stiffness Actuator
An Evolutionary Approach for the Optimal Design of the iCub mk.3 Parallel Wrist

summary: In order to reduce the share of the motive power required to drive the robot's links, with the aim of increasing its payload-to- weight ratio, this article studies the best way to relocate the actuators (inertial load) but not complicate the joint kinematics. For this, several Parallel Kinematic Mechanisms (PKMs) were considered, namely a 4-UU mechanism, a spherical 5-bar mechanism and a spherical 6-bar mechanism, with gimbal-like rotations. Computer-Aided Design (CAD) modelling and simulations exploring the workspaces for each of these mechanisms was performed. The complete workspace and isotropy analyses comparing these mechanisms to a gimbal system are presented. The general observations suggest that these mechanisms posses a non-uniform workspace with a "warping" behaviour. However, the spherical six bar mechanism proves to be the best solution so far with isotropy nearly = 0.9 throughout its workspace.
title: Comparison of Workspace Analysis for Different Spherical Parallel Mechanisms

content:
More recently, our group started directing part of its effort to the study and development of two degrees of freedom (DOF) mechanisms to be employed as robot wrists. As part of these studies, we were the first to report on the asymmetric and anisotropic properties of the workspace of N-UU type mechanisms (a.k.a. OmniWrist III type mechanisms). The main findings of this work were presented in:
Shah, D., Metta, G., & Parmiggiani, A. (2018). Workspace analysis and the effect of geometric parameters for parallel mechanisms of the N-UU class. In ASME Int. Conf. on Design Engineering - IDETC/CIE. Quebec City, Canada: American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
summary: Given their large, singularity-free workspace, 2DOF mechanisms of the N-UU class are extremely promising for use in robotic wrists. This explores possible solutions to be employed for the iCub forearm-hand assembly.
title: N-UU mechanisms

summary: N-UU class mechanisms, exemplified by the Omni-Wrist III, are compact parallel kinematic mechanisms (PKM) with large singularity free workspaces. These characteristics make them ideal for applications in robot wrists. This article presents the detailed kinematic and workspace analysis for four N-UU class mechanisms. More in detail, the equations defining the mechanismï¿½s moving platform kinematics are derived as a function of the motion of the input links; these are then used to explore the mechanismï¿½s workspace. These results are furthermore validated by comparing them to the results obtained from CAD-based simulations. The analyses suggests that the workspace of the mechanism is non-uniform, with a ï¿½warpingï¿½ behaviour that occurs in an asymmetric fashion in a specific region of the workspace. Furthermore we show how the rotation of the input links, which mainly actuates the yaw and pitch angles of the mechanism, also causes unwanted coupled rotations along the roll axis.
title: Workspace Analysis and the Effect of Geometric Parameters for Parallel Mechanisms of the N-UU Class
A parallel kinematic mechanism for the torso of a humanoid robot: Design, construction and validation
The Design and Validation of the R1 Personal Humanoid
From science to technology: Orientation and mobility in blind children and adults
Head and Face Design for a new Humanoid Service Robot
A new cost effective robot hand for the iCub humanoid
Design and Validation of a Talking Face for the iCub

content:
The years 2015 and 2016 were entirely devoted to a new project, strongly endorsed by the scientific direction of IIT. The ambitious aim of the project was to design, build and demonstrate a robot functionally equivalent to the iCub humanoid but at one-twentieth (1⁄20) of the cost.
This goal was pursued with a design-for-manufacturing approach, novel solutions for robot mechanisms, and by a wide use of polymeric materials.
The project was of a rather large scale, involving over 30 people working in 7 different institutions in different geographical locations (Italy, Spain, Switzerland and New Zealand). The total budget of the project was around 1.1M€ (including personnel, consumables, and external services).
During this period, I managed the project and acted as the main reference person for all development related issues. As part of my project management duty, I introduced an AGILE working methodology, which largely increased the efficiency and proficiency of the development team. I personally designed several robot sub-assemblies. Over the course of 16 months, we developed from scratch three new types of robotic actuators and a novel motor control methodology.
The first prototype of the R1 robot was demonstrated in April 2016. The main results of this project were published in:
Parmiggiani, A., Fiorio, L., Scalzo, A., Sureshbabu, A. V., Randazzo, M., Maggiali, M., … Metta, G. (2017). The design and validation of the R1 personal humanoid. In IEEE/RSJ Int. Conf. on Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS). DOI: 10.1109/IROS.2017.8202224
summary:
The goal of the R1 project was to bring the technology developed in the iCub project one step closer to the market. This problem was addressed with a design-for-manufacturing approach, novel solutions for robot mechanisms, and by a wide use of polymeric materials.
The first complete robot prototype was demonstrated in just 16 months from the beginning of the project.
title: R1
An articulated talking face for the iCub
An alternative approach to robot safety
On the performance of actuators with harmonic drive speed reducers
Sensorimotor Coordination in a Humanoid Robot: Building Intelligence on the iCub
Stiction Compensation in Agonist-Antagonist Variable Stiffness Actuators
On the effects of internal stiction in pnrVIA actuators
Quantitative Evaluation of Standing Stabilization Using Stiff and Compliant Actuators.

content:
Among the various sub-systems that I developed for the iCub robot was an articulated talking face developed jointly with Prof. Gerard Bailly and Dr Frederic Elisei at the University of Grenoble. The head featured an articulated jaw and four independent lip movements actuated by five motors. The head was covered by a specially designed elastic tissue cover whose hemlines at the lips are attached to the motors via connecting linkages. This variant of the iCub head was later employed for psychometric studies on the perception of speech. The main results of this work were published in:
Parmiggiani, A., Randazzo, M., Maggiali, M., Metta, G., Elisei, F., & Bailly, G. (2015). Design and validation of a talking face for the iCub. International Journal of Humanoid Robotics, DOI:10.1142/S0219843615500267
summary: This result of this project, carried out jointly with Prof. Gerard Bailly and Dr Frederic Elisei at the University of Grenoble, was the creation of an articulated talking face developed. The head featured an articulated jaw, four independent lip movements and was covered by a specially designed elastic tissue.
title: iCub expressive face
The mechatronic design of the new legs of the iCub robot
pnrVSA: human-like actuator with non-linear springs in agonist-antagonist configuration
Control of a single Degree of Freedom Noise Rejecting - Variable Impedance Actuator
The design of the iCub humanoid robot

content:
In 2012 I completed the new design of the legs of the iCub robot. This project was the result of a collaboration with colleagues of the Advanced Robotics department at IIT. The most relevant new feature of the system was the addition of series elastic actuators (SEA). The original SEA design was adapted and optimized through the development of a custom spring based on the curved beam concept. SEA were later used for comparative studies on stiff and compliant robot actuation. A description of the system is presented in:
Parmiggiani, A., Metta, G., & Tsagarakis, N. (2012). The mechatronic design of the new legs of the iCub robot. In IEEE-RAS Int. Conf. on Humanoid Robots (HUMANOIDS) (pp. 481–486). DOI: 10.1109/HUMANOIDS.2012.6651563
summary: This project, carried out in tight collaboration with colleagues of the Advanced Robotics department, allowed the improvement of the iCub legs sub-assembly and the addition of series elastic actuators (SEA) to the main leg joints.
title: iCub SEA legs
Water/air performance analysis of a fluidic muscle
Torque control: a study on the iCub humanoid robot

content:
Between 2010 and 2011 I focused on the development of several hardware modules that laid the basis for the mechanics of the second version of the iCub robot (iCub2). Besides the original design work, I integrated advanced sensing solutions developed by colleagues specializing in micro-electronics. The new version of the robot integrated an improved system for the position sensing of the electric motor rotors, field oriented control for the brushless DC motors, additional acceleration and angular velocity MEMS sensors, and a full-body skin with approximately 4000 independent pressure measurement points. A detailed description of the results of the project is presented in:
Parmiggiani, A., Maggiali, M., Natale, L., Nori, F., Schmitz, A., Tsagarakis, N., … Metta, G. (2012). The design of the iCub humanoid robot. International Journal of Humanoid Robotics, 9. DOI: 10.1142/S0219843612500272
summary: Initial testing of the iCub platform highlighted the need for further improvements. This project addressed the most important limitations by completing the second design iteration of the iCub humanoid.
title: iCub2
A force sensor for the control of a human-like tendon driven neck
Joint torque sensing for the upper-body of the iCub humanoid robot
